G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, § 3, as the claims concern a residential tenancy and alleged violations of the Massachusetts landlord-tenant laws.

**Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, \u0.proposition: Under **Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, § 14**, a landlord shall not directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of leased residential premises.

**Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714 (.raw_text: **Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714 (1977) (landlord liable when actions substantially interfere with tenant’s use)
**Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714 (.proposition: Defendant’s failure and refusal to maintain adequate heat in the premises—after notice of the defective conditions—constitutes a constructive interference in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and Massachusetts case law, including but not limited to:
**Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714 (.support_reasoning: Blackett v. Olanoff concerns noise and disturbance from a bar operated on premises leased by the landlord and held that such landlord-created and controllable conditions constituted a breach of quiet enjoyment/constructive eviction. The case does not address inadequate heat, G.L. c. 186, § 14, or failure to maintain heat after notice, and thus does not directly support the specific proposition about lack of heat as constructive interference under that statute, even though it is generally consistent with the broader principle of landlord liability for substantial interference.
**Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714 (.relevant_excerpt: There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done. Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124, 127 (1959) (failure to supply light, heat, power, and elevator services). Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass. 375, 381 (1942) (intrusions of smoke and soot...).

**Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91 (1982.raw_text: **Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (noise and water leaks giving rise to breach of covenant of quiet enjoyment)
**Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91 (1982.proposition: Defendant’s failure and refusal to maintain adequate heat in the premises—after notice of the defective conditions—constitutes a constructive interference in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and Massachusetts case law, including but not limited to:
**Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91 (1982.support_reasoning: The case squarely interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 and holds that a landlord’s reckless (and not necessarily intentional) failure to maintain essential sanitary/habitable conditions after notice can constitute an interference with quiet enjoyment under the statute. While the facts involve flooding rather than lack of heat, the decision’s reasoning is not limited to water leaks; it broadly states that unsanitary conditions causing serious interference with tenancy and resulting personal injury are within § 14’s scope. Thus it provides supportive, though not heat-specific, authority for treating failure to provide adequate heat after notice as a constructive interference under § 14.
**Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91 (1982.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 belongs to a body of statutes establishing tenants’ remedies against landlords who fail to provide safe and sanitary housing… These statutes are designed to facilitate enforcement of State housing regulations and to provide relief for tenants deprived of decent homes… The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent… Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14…. [T]he combination in § 14 of both actual and consequential damages… suggests that the Legislature intended to include all reasonably foreseeable losses — personal as well as economic — within the scope of statutory recovery.”}

**Hemingway v. First Nat\u2019l Bank & T.raw_text: **Hemingway v. First Nat’l Bank & Trust Co. of Boston**, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (recognizing tenant’s right to habitable premises)
**Hemingway v. First Nat\u2019l Bank & T.proposition: Defendant’s failure and refusal to maintain adequate heat in the premises—after notice of the defective conditions—constitutes a constructive interference in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and Massachusetts case law, including but not limited to:
**Hemingway v. First Nat\u2019l Bank & T.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Hemingway is a concurrence/dissent focused on recognizing an implied warranty of habitability and aligning that warranty with State Sanitary Code standards. It does not interpret G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it address lack of heat as a constructive interference or constructive eviction under that statute. While the broader case is important for habitability, this excerpt does not provide authority for the specific proposition that failure to maintain heat constitutes constructive interference in violation of c. 186, § 14.
**Hemingway v. First Nat\u2019l Bank & T.relevant_excerpt: “I agree with the majority of the court that, at least as to dwelling units, the time has come to reconsider the rule so long imbedded in our law of landlord and tenant that ‘[t]here is no implied agreement, apart from fraud, that the demised premises are or will continue to be fit for occupancy or safe and in good repair [and that] [t]he tenant takes the premises as he finds them and there is no obligation on the landlord to make repairs.’”

**Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson**, 37.raw_text: **Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson**, 379 Mass. 196 (1979) (heating deficiencies and habitability issues constitute interference with quiet enjoyment)
**Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson**, 37.proposition: Defendant’s failure and refusal to maintain adequate heat in the premises—after notice of the defective conditions—constitutes a constructive interference in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and Massachusetts case law, including but not limited to:
**Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson**, 37.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly holds that loss of heat and hot water are material breaches of the implied warranty of habitability and allow rent abatement once the landlord has notice, regardless of fault or reasonable repair efforts. However, the case is framed entirely as a warranty-of-habitability/rent-abatement decision and does not interpret or apply G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it use the language of ‘constructive interference’ with quiet enjoyment. Thus it supports the idea that failure to maintain heat after notice breaches habitability (with rent abatement) but not that it constitutes a constructive interference under § 14.
**Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson**, 37.relevant_excerpt: “He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability. The judge ruled further that the tenant is allowed to abate the rent from the date the landlord had notice of the breach of the warranty of habitability. We hold that the tenant’s obligation abates as soon as the landlord has notice that premises fail to comply with the requirements of the warranty of habitability. The landlord’s lack of fault and reasonable efforts to repair do not prolong the duty to pay full rent.”

**Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth.**, 378.raw_text: **Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth.**, 378 Mass. 758 (1979) (landlord liability for recurring, unremedied conditions)
**Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth.**, 378.proposition: Defendant’s failure and refusal to maintain adequate heat in the premises—after notice of the defective conditions—constitutes a constructive interference in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and Massachusetts case law, including but not limited to:
**Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth.**, 378.support_reasoning: The case involves landlord liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 for interference with quiet enjoyment due to persistent physical defects (a leaky roof and defective floors), but it does not concern inadequate heat or heating systems. The SJC affirms that the landlord’s failure to repair serious, recurring defects after notice can constitute interference with quiet enjoyment under § 14, yet there is no discussion of heat, nor a specific holding that failure to maintain adequate heat constitutes constructive interference. Thus, it is analogous authority on quiet enjoyment and recurring unremedied conditions, but does not directly support the heat-related proposition.
**Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth.**, 378.relevant_excerpt: The BHA does not challenge the judge’s conclusion that its failures to repair the leaky roof and the defective floors were breaches of its implied warranty of habitability or his determination that the leaky roof interfered with the plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises. … Section 14 of G. L. c. 186 expands the measure of damages to include all "actual and consequential damages" where, as here, there has been a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

**Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.**, 417.raw_text: **Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.**, 417 Mass. 273 (1994) (quiet enjoyment protected from landlord’s acts or omissions)
**Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.**, 417.proposition: Defendant’s failure and refusal to maintain adequate heat in the premises—after notice of the defective conditions—constitutes a constructive interference in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and Massachusetts case law, including but not limited to:
**Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.**, 417.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
**Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.**, 417.support_reasoning: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority does interpret and apply G.L. c. 186, § 14, but it involves interference from pervasive criminal/drug activity and the landlord’s failure to take reasonable security‑related measures in common areas—not failure to maintain heat or physical building systems. The case confirms that serious interference caused by a landlord’s acts or omissions can breach quiet enjoyment, but it does not address inadequate heat or constructive interference via lack of heat, so it does not support this specific heating‑related proposition.
**Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.**, 417.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

**Davis v. Comerford**, 483 Mass. 164 (2.raw_text: **Davis v. Comerford**, 483 Mass. 164 (2019) (affirming that negligent omissions causing loss of essential services can violate G.L. c. 186, § 14)
**Davis v. Comerford**, 483 Mass. 164 (2.proposition: Defendant’s failure and refusal to maintain adequate heat in the premises—after notice of the defective conditions—constitutes a constructive interference in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and Massachusetts case law, including but not limited to:

**Trustees of Cambridge Point Condo. Tru.raw_text: **Trustees of Cambridge Point Condo. Trust v. Cambridge Point, LLC**, 478 Mass. 697 (2018) (discussing substantial interference standard)
**Trustees of Cambridge Point Condo. Tru.proposition: Defendant’s failure and refusal to maintain adequate heat in the premises—after notice of the defective conditions—constitutes a constructive interference in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and Massachusetts case law, including but not limited to:

**Young v. Patukonis**, 24 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: **Young v. Patukonis**, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987) (prolonged heat loss constitutes interference with quiet enjoyment)
**Young v. Patukonis**, 24 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Defendant’s failure and refusal to maintain adequate heat in the premises—after notice of the defective conditions—constitutes a constructive interference in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and Massachusetts case law, including but not limited to:
**Young v. Patukonis**, 24 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the landlord’s statutory duty to provide heat and hot water under the State Sanitary Code and holds that an oral agreement shifting that duty to the tenant is unenforceable because the regulation requires a written agreement. However, the decision does not address G.L. c. 186, § 14, constructive interference with quiet enjoyment, or prolonged heat loss as a violation of that statute. It therefore does not provide authority for the specific proposition that failure to maintain adequate heat after notice constitutes constructive interference under § 14.
**Young v. Patukonis**, 24 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “The State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.190 and 410.201 (1983), provides that the owner of a dwelling ‘shall’ supply heat and hot water ‘except and to the extent that the occupant is required to supply the fuel under a written letting agreement.’ … The plain and unambiguous language of the regulation indicates that a writing is required when the obligation to provide heat and hot water is transferred to the tenant.”

**Lowery v. Robinson**, 13 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: **Lowery v. Robinson**, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982) (landlord’s failure to maintain building services interferes with quiet enjoyment)
**Lowery v. Robinson**, 13 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Defendant’s failure and refusal to maintain adequate heat in the premises—after notice of the defective conditions—constitutes a constructive interference in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and Massachusetts case law, including but not limited to:
**Lowery v. Robinson**, 13 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The case squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and it rejects the landlord’s financial inability as a defense. Although the opinion does not explicitly discuss a separate “notice” requirement, it clearly establishes that lack of heat is a constructive interference with quiet enjoyment actionable under § 14, which is the core of the cited proposition.
**Lowery v. Robinson**, 13 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season … seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’ … On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to (a) a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14….”
